|Title=First-line investigations for facial pain
|Description=None

|Contributors=
|Order=11}}
- Examinations are guided by questioning and a thorough clinical examination of the face, ears and oral cavity.

- Dental panoramic: in the event of dental pain

- Full ENT examination (otoscopy and fibroscopy)

- CT scan of the face and sinuses (without and with injection)

- If suspicious lesion of the buccal mucosa: biopsy

- If the local examination of the face, ears and oral cavity is normal, and/or the pain is recent and unusual and/or there is an associated headache, the reasoning is the same as for acute (recent) or chronic headache <u>('''see''' item 100)</u>.

question.title: What is the next step in the investigation of facial pain if the local examination of the face, ears, and oral cavity is normal?

option_a.title: Biopsy of the buccal mucosa
option_a.description: A procedure to examine the tissue of the cheek

option_b.title: CT scan of the face and sinuses
option_b.description: An imaging test to visualize the face and sinuses

option_c.title: Full ENT examination
option_c.description: A comprehensive examination of the ear, nose, and throat

option_d.title: Dental panoramic
option_d.description: An imaging test of the teeth and jaw

correct_option.title: A
correct_option.description: The correct letter of the answer
